description:
Camelus ferus, commonly known as the wild Bactrian camel, is a species of large, two-humped camel native to the remote and arid regions of Central Asia. This endangered species is the wild ancestor of the domesticated Bactrian camel (Camelus bactrianus).

The wild Bactrian camel is a robust, hairy animal adapted to survive in the harsh desert and mountainous environments of its natural habitat. It has a distinctive appearance with two humps on its back, which serve as fat reserves that can be metabolized for energy and water during periods of food and water scarcity. Its thick, woolly coat helps insulate it from the extreme temperatures of its environment.

Camelus ferus is a highly social species, living in small herds led by a dominant female. These herds exhibit complex social behaviors and communication through vocalizations, body language, and scent marking. The wild Bactrian camel is an herbivore, subsisting on a diverse range of desert vegetation, including grasses, shrubs, and even some succulent plants.

Due to habitat loss, poaching, and competition with domestic livestock, the wild Bactrian camel is considered Critically Endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique and adaptable species and its fragile desert ecosystem.
